Award.AwardTitle: Simulation and modeling of the interactions of liquid turbulent eddies and gas bubbles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bolotnov, Igor
1333993

Reliable prediction of multiphase turbulent flows using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) is important in a wide range of engineering applications (e.g., flows in nuclear reactors, chemical processing plants, heat exchangers etc). While some multiphase flows can be successfully modeled, many questions remain unanswered regarding the interactions between bubbles and the turbulence. Specifically, multiphase CFD approaches utilize interfacial forces (e.g., lift, drag forces) to predict the bubble distribution in the flow. However, the influence of the turbulence on the interfacial forces is not fully understood.

Intellectual Merit :
The project objective is to quantify bubble/turbulence interactions in a specific set of flow conditions by analyzing experimentally validated interface tracking simulations and to create new turbulence spectrum that accounts for interfacial forces to be used in multiphase CFD and multiphase large-eddy simulations (LES). Advanced finite-element based flow solver (PHASTA) with Level-Set method for interface tracking will be used to perform the bubble/turbulence interaction studies. This code has been successfully applied to large scale direct numerical simulation (DNS) of turbulent flows in various geometries, as well as interface tracking simulations (including bubbly channel flow, annular flow). The proposed research will test the following hypotheses: (i) Bubbles deposit energy to the liquid turbulence eddies of the same size and deformability of a bubble controls the amount of energy, and may result in reverse energy transfer from the liquid turbulence; (ii) The energy deposition into the liquid turbulence is affected by the presence of the wall and the bubble/wall interactions modify the law of the wall and affect shear-induced energy production; (iii) The lateral bubble distribution in turbulent shear flow is governed by interfacial forces which strongly depend on bubble/turbulence interaction.

Broader Impacts :
The success of this project will be instrumental in developing new multiphase flow models that have the ability to design advanced engineering systems with multiphase CFD. More accurate models for this type of flows can allow the construction of more efficient nuclear power plants, chemical processing plants as well as bring two-phase flow applications in other areas of engineering. High-fidelity interface tracking simulations will be introduced in graduate level courses on thermal hydraulics in the Nuclear Engineering Department. In addition, basic concepts related to the proposed research will be presented to high school students through the yearly Young Investigator's Summer Program in Nuclear Technology organized by the Nuclear Engineering Department's Outreach Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Prediction of gas fraction distribution in multiphase turbulent flows using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) is an important capability in a wide range of engineering applications. Nuclear reactor core flows, chemical processing plants, heat exchangers, boiler designs in electrical power plants would all benefit from better understanding of bubbly flow behavior. While some multiphase flows can be successfully modeled, many questions remain unanswered regarding the interactions between bubbles and the turbulence. Specifically, multiphase CFD approaches utilize interfacial forces (e.g., lift, drag forces) to predict the bubble distribution in the flow. However, the influence of the turbulence on the interfacial forces is not fully understood. In this project, we have made several steps to better quantify and understand those interactions using the controlled single bubble numerical methodology to evaluate the influence of several parameters on bubble / liquid interaction.


Intellectual Merit 
Under this research grant, we investigated how bubbles interact with liquid flow and proposed several updated models in our publications. In all our objectives, we have used advanced finite-element based high resolution modeling approach to resolve the fluid flow phenomena using direct numerical simulation (DNS) approach. We utilized Level-Set method to track the deformable interface between the gas and the liquid, which accounts for surface tension effects and different physical properties of the fluids on each side of the interface. Those methods have been previously implemented in the highly-parallel research flow solver, PHASTA, which has been used in this study. This code has been successfully applied to large scale direct numerical simulation (DNS) of turbulent flows in various geometries, as well as interface tracking simulations (including bubbly channel flow, annular flow) in the past. As part of this project, we have developed, implemented, verified and validated the bubbly control capability which allowed us to investigate the bubble interactions over significant amount of time (by DNS standards) without the need of large computational domain which would make those studies too expensive. The performed research has clearly demonstrated that traditionally computationally expensive DNS approach can now be used for a wide range of parametric studies with relatively routine simulations which require only a few hours each when using 64 or 128 computational cores per simulation. In the following paragraphs, we will highlight some of the results which this effort delivered.

Direct validation against available experimental data for single bubble drag and lift forces has been performed. The data-based correlation for different bubble Reynolds numbers has been used for simulation-obtained drag coefficient validation; and variable bubble size resulting in various bubble deformability levels (quantified through non-dimensional Eotvos number) have been directly compared with experimental images and observed lift coefficient values.

Separate task has been devoted to study bubble-induced turbulence. A novel methodology has been expanded for this effort which allowed to generate uniform turbulent flow using larger meshes and transfer this solution as an inflow boundary condition to a smaller, single-bubble simulation. Mean inflow velocity has been adjusted to various levels to have parametric studies performed to vary relative velocity around the fixed bubble. Bubble deformability studies also yielded very interesting results on bubble-induced turbulence (BIT). One direct observation giving DNS-like insight into the flow patterns: the BIT at the bubble location is negative for most cases (and positive, as expected, in the bubble wake location). The liquid / interface interaction and flow around the bubble results in the local energy transfer from turbulent kinetic energy to mean flow kinetic energy. This energy is transferred back in the wake, in addition to local shear produced energy due to interaction with the bubble interface.


Broader Impacts 
The research performed under this grant brought better understanding of the interfacial forces behavior in various laminar and turbulent conditions, as well as quantified bubble induced turbulence for some selected scenarios. Improved modeling of multiphase flows have a big impact on safety of nuclear reactor cores in normal operating conditions as well as predictive capabilities in some accident scenarios. One of the major issues is avoiding so-called departure from nucleate boiling (DNB) which related to high concentration of steam bubbles near the heated wall and may result in the heater melting (and nuclear fuel structural disintegration in reactors).  

This grant has furthered the education and training of several graduate and undergraduate students. One graduate student was funded by this grant and completed his PhD, while several undergraduate students participated in research project sponsored by or related to this grant. Graduate student have participated in the writing of 4 journal papers (3 published) and 7 peer-reviewed conference papers where the results of this research effort were presented. The research has been highlighted in 3 international presentations in China, Germany and Japan and several national meetings and separate visits of universities and national laboratories. High-school students were presented with some results during the annual summer program in Nuclear Engineering.
